search.slidetext: start course start course start course learn how to take your professionalism to the next level. this course will present you to the standards in a business environment. it will also introduce you to the best practices in various business occasions. business etiquette yomna zahran

list professional acts during a business meal with more than 70% of accuracy. objective 06 06 list professional acts during a business meeting with more than 70% of accuracy. objective 05 05 list professional acts in a networking event with more than 70% of accuracy. objective 04 04 evaluate acceptable attitude in the workplace on a scale of 5. objective 03 03 select the proper actions in the workplace with 85% of accuracy using the code of conduct. objective 02 02 define standards of appearance in the workplace with 100% of accuracy using the code of conduct objective 01 01 course objectives after completion of this course learners will be able to :
continue continue continue standards in a work environment part 1 type any informative comments here continue continue continue standards in a work environment part 1

appearance appearance appearance appearance actions actions actions actions attitude attitude attitude attitude weâ€™re going to introduce you to some general tips you need to consider in the workplace regarding your appearance, actions, and attitude: part 1

consider packing an extra set of clothes in your car or bring an extra blazer to put on over your clothes if clients visit unexpectedly. tips back to menu keep your beard trim and tidy. tips never underestimate the power of a smile! tips avoid bright colors. clothes that are too flashy can be distracting and the visual equivalent of shouting. tips maintain positive body language. arms relaxed by your side . donâ€™t clench your hands, keep them open . maintain at least 4 feet of personal space . tips maintain positive facial language, but do not exaggerate. eye contact is highly important, however, grab your eyes away every 4:5 seconds. tips know the dress code and do the basics. iron your shirt, practice good hygiene, and grab a few breath mints. smells matter a lot, so go light on the cologne or perfumes. tips tips

work co-operatively with others in order to achieve objectives. tips back to menu avoid gossip. let it not spread! tips if you have free time to bake cookies or some other treats, it can be a really nice gesture for your coworkers-especially if youâ€™re celebrating a big win. tips when communicating, choose your words, tone of voice, and put your point across in a respectful manner. tips accept new projects that youâ€™ve never worked on in the past, despite feeling nervous. tips if one of your coworkers asks you for help in completing a task, you should generally say yes. tips appear just on time! tips tips

if something in the workplace is bothering you, reach out to the human resources department or your supervisor to resolve the issue so it doesnâ€™t interfere with your work. tips back to menu aggressive or abusive behavior, such as shouting or personal insults, are not â€“ for any reason accepted. tips while advancing in your career, you should do your best to remain open-minded. tips while itâ€™s never fun to work a holiday, a weekend, or to do â€œsomeone elseâ€™s job,â€ be flexible. tips avoid being sarcastic or offensive when disagreeing on someoneâ€™s opinion. tips always show your boss respect, even if there isnâ€™t much of an age difference between you and him/her. tips avoid having a personal conversation at your desk. step outside. tips tips
continue continue continue how to handle various occasions part 2
occasion #1 networking event

stand near the group and make eye contact and smile. when someone acknowledges you, it's a great time to introduce yourself. 2 3 best practices reduce nerves by focusing on making one friend. try to help someone. find a person standing on their own and start a conversation with them. 3 1 2 best practices take networking opportunities seriously, especially when youâ€™re first starting on the job. 2 1 best practices best practices 1

make a polite exit. let them know it was nice meeting them, and smile as you say goodbye. this is the area to place your text content. it might describe the image to the right or maybe the image supports the text. title 02 use some open-ended questions as conversation starters. title 01 best practices 6 5 4 this is the area to place your text content. it might describe the image to the right or maybe the image supports the text. title 03 when you're talking to someone, be in the moment. don't look over their shoulder to see who else is around, or check your phone during the conversation. use some open-ended questions as conversation starters. title 01 best practices 6 5 4 this is the area to place your text content. it might describe the image to the right or maybe the image supports the text. title 03 this is the area to place your text content. it might describe the image to the right or maybe the image supports the text. title 02 use some open-ended questions as conversation starters. ask how they know the host, or how long they've been a part of the group. best practices 6 5 4 this is the area to place your text content. it might describe the image to the right or maybe the image supports the text. title 03 this is the area to place your text content. it might describe the image to the right or maybe the image supports the text. title 02 4
occasion #2 business meeting

sit up straight, smile, and give your full attention. sometimes outside noises can't be avoided. but, whenever possible, try to minimize them. it's fine to use mute when you're on a group call and you're not talking. make sure to log in to the meeting 10 minutes early to troubleshoot any connection problems. video meeting in-person meeting insert title insert title video meeting asking questions-no matter how silly they may seem-will help you clarify expectations. use agendas to come prepared with any data or materials you may need. if there is someone you haven't met before, make sure to introduce yourself. before you leave the room, push in your chair and pick up after yourself. in-person meeting insert title insert title video meeting in-person meeting 1 2
occasion #3 business meal

if you made the invitation to the meal, be prepared to pay the bill. tipping appropriately is important. best practices if you're not sure of their preference, it's best to match the formality of the restaurant to the level of the business being conducted or to the status of your guest. best practices when you're hosting the meal, make sure to consider your guest's preferences. best practices best practices if youâ€™re the host

if you need to get the waiter's attention, make eye contact or raise your index finger rather than raising your empty glass, pointing, or calling out. best practices as a guest, don't bring anyone who wasn't invited directly by the host. best practices if you enjoyed the meal, it's nice to also mention how much you liked it. best practices if you're a guest at a business meal, make sure to thank your host. best practices best practices if youâ€™re the guest
letâ€™s do this! congratulations! now, you have a solid understanding of our lesson. congratulations!
scenario 03 scenario 02 scenario 01

nice try. but fast food is not the best choice. try again offer your client some suggestions and take special notes about their dietary preferences. you donâ€™t want to take a vegan to a steakhouse! that is right! nice try. but â€œromanticâ€ is not the best setting when itâ€™s a business meal. try again nice try. but they may not necessarily be interested! try again take them to your favorite sports bar thatâ€™s showing an important game a a a a b b b b take them to an upscale french restaurant with a romantic ambience scenario 1 c c c c ask for their preference and pick an appropriate restaurant d d d d invite the client to your office to eat fast food you invite an out-of-town client to dinner to discuss work; you should:

hi! nice to meet you! try again. you mispronounced my name, it's smythe, not smith. try again. hey timmy, nice to meet ya! try again. a pleasure meeting you, mr. monroe. thatâ€™s right! hi! nice to meet you! d you mispronounced my name, it's smythe, not smith. c hey timmy, nice to meet ya! b a pleasure meeting you, mr. monroe. choose your response by clicking an item below. let me introduce you to mr. monroe. this is my colleague smythe. a

continue continue continue continue continue continue rule #1 : rule #2 : rule #3 : rule #4 : compare your answers: according to the tips of professional attitude at work, classify the following rules: drag-and-drop in the boxes know the dress code so you can align with fashion trends. rule #1 rule #2 help coworkers whenever they need you. reach out to the hrd to discuss any workplace issue. rule #3 rule #4 avoid eye contact at all because itâ€™s embarrassing.
